expanded_description: This section introduces Newton's Law of Universal Gravitation, which describes the gravitational attraction between any two objects with mass. It is a fundamental force that governs the motion of planets, the orbits of satellites, the tides, and the familiar weight we experience on Earth. The law states that every particle in the universe attracts every other particle with a force that is proportional to the product of their masses and inversely proportional to the square of the distance between them.

core_concept.principle: Newton's Law of Universal Gravitation: Every particle in the universe attracts every other particle with a force that is directly proportional to the product of their masses and inversely proportional to the square of the distance between them. The force acts along the line joining the two particles. Mathematically, $F = G \frac{m_1 m_2}{r^2}$, where $G$ is the universal gravitational constant.
core_concept.explanation: This law unifies terrestrial and celestial motion: the same force that causes an apple to fall also keeps the Moon in orbit around Earth. It is an inverse‑square law, meaning the force weakens rapidly with distance. The constant $G$ is extremely small, making gravity noticeable only when at least one of the masses is huge (like a planet or star).

image.alt: Diagram showing two masses separated by distance r with an arrow indicating the gravitational attraction between them
image.caption: The gravitational force between two masses is attractive, along the line connecting them, and depends on the product of their masses and the inverse square of the distance.

sections.introduction: Newton realized that the force that makes an apple fall is the same force that holds the Moon in orbit. He formulated this idea into a universal law that applies to all masses, anywhere in the universe.

key_concept.definition: The gravitational force between two point masses $m_1$ and $m_2$ separated by a distance $r$ is given by $F = G \frac{m_1 m_2}{r^2}$. The force is always attractive, directed along the line joining the masses. $G$ is the universal gravitational constant, $G = 6.67 \times 10^{-11} \, \text{N}\cdot\text{m}^2/\text{kg}^2$.
key_concept.context: This law applies to any two masses, whether they are atoms, apples, planets, or galaxies. For extended spherical objects, the distance $r$ is measured between their centers, as Newton proved that a uniform sphere attracts as if all its mass were concentrated at its center.

principles.statement: The gravitational force is inversely proportional to the square of the distance between the masses. If the distance doubles, the force becomes one‑fourth as strong.
principles.application: This rapid decrease with distance explains why we feel only Earth's gravity and not the gravity of distant stars.
principles.example: A satellite at twice Earth's radius (from the center) experiences one‑fourth the gravitational force it would have at the surface.

principles.statement: The force is directly proportional to the product of the two masses. If either mass doubles, the force doubles. If both double, the force quadruples.
principles.application: This means that the gravitational force between two objects is stronger if either object is more massive.
principles.example: The gravitational force between Earth and the Moon is much larger than the force between a person and a car because Earth and Moon have huge masses.

principles.statement: Gravitational force is a vector. Each mass experiences a force of the same magnitude but in opposite directions (Newton's third law). When more than two masses are present, forces add vectorially.
principles.application: For problems with multiple masses, we must compute the net gravitational force on a given mass by summing the force vectors from each other mass.
principles.example: A mass located between two larger masses may experience forces in opposite directions; the net force is the vector sum.

image.alt: Illustration of the inverse square law: as distance increases, the force lines spread over a larger area
image.caption: The inverse square nature of gravity: the force spreads out over the surface of an imaginary sphere, so intensity decreases as $1/r^2$.

sections.introduction: The constant $G$ in Newton's law was not determined by Newton; it was first measured experimentally more than a century later by Henry Cavendish.

key_concept.definition: $G = 6.67 \times 10^{-11} \, \text{N}\cdot\text{m}^2/\text{kg}^2$ is the universal gravitational constant. It is a fundamental constant of nature, the same everywhere in the universe.
key_concept.context: The extremely small value of $G$ explains why gravitational forces are negligible between ordinary‑sized objects. We only notice gravity when at least one mass is astronomical in scale.

principles.statement: In 1798, Henry Cavendish measured $G$ using a torsion balance. He observed the tiny gravitational attraction between lead spheres and calculated $G$ from the measured force.
principles.application: This experiment also allowed the mass of Earth to be determined for the first time, using $g = GM_E/R_E^2$.
principles.example: Cavendish's result was remarkably accurate, within 1% of today's accepted value.

worked_examples.title: Calculating Gravitational Force
worked_examples.problem: Two 1000 kg masses are placed 2.0 m apart. What is the gravitational force between them? ($G = 6.67 \times 10^{-11} \, \text{N}\cdot\text{m}^2/\text{kg}^2$)
worked_examples.concept_applied: Even with large masses (1000 kg), the force is tiny because $G$ is so small.

sections.introduction: Weight is the gravitational force exerted by Earth (or another celestial body) on an object. Newton's law of gravitation provides a deeper understanding of weight and why $g$ varies with location.

key_concept.definition: An object of mass $m$ on Earth's surface experiences a gravitational force $F_g = G \frac{M_E m}{R_E^2}$, where $M_E$ is Earth's mass and $R_E$ is its radius. This force is what we call weight, $W = mg$, so $g = G \frac{M_E}{R_E^2}$.
key_concept.context: This shows that $g$ is not universal; it depends on the mass and radius of the planet. On different planets, $g$ differs.

principles.statement: Equating $mg = G M_E m / R_E^2$ gives $g = G M_E / R_E^2$.
principles.application: Using Earth's mass $5.98 \times 10^{24}$ kg and radius $6.38 \times 10^6$ m, we can compute $g$.

principles.statement: At a height $h$ above Earth's surface, the distance from Earth's center is $R_E + h$, so $g_h = G M_E / (R_E + h)^2$.
principles.application: As altitude increases, $g$ decreases. This affects satellite orbits and the weight of astronauts.
principles.example: At $h = 200$ km, $g$ is about $9.2$ m/s², slightly less than at the surface.

worked_examples.title: Finding $g$ on Another Planet
worked_examples.problem: Mars has mass $6.42 \times 10^{23}$ kg and radius $3.40 \times 10^6$ m. What is the acceleration due to gravity on Mars?
worked_examples.concept_applied: The formula $g = GM/R^2$ works for any spherical body.

worked_examples.title: Weight at Altitude
worked_examples.problem: An astronaut weighs 800 N on Earth's surface. What would he weigh at an altitude of 300 km? (Earth radius $R_E = 6.38 \times 10^6$ m, $M_E = 5.98 \times 10^{24}$ kg)
worked_examples.concept_applied: Weight decreases with altitude as $g$ decreases.

sections.introduction: When more than two masses are present, the net gravitational force on any one mass is the vector sum of the forces exerted by each of the other masses individually.

key_concept.definition: The principle of superposition: The total gravitational force on a mass due to a collection of other masses is the vector sum of the forces from each mass: $\vec{F}_{\text{net}} = \sum \vec{F}_i$.
key_concept.context: This allows us to solve problems involving multiple bodies, such as a spacecraft influenced by Earth, Moon, and Sun, or a mass between two larger masses.

principles.statement: Forces are vectors, so direction matters. When forces are not collinear, we must add them using components.
principles.application: Resolve each force into x and y components, sum components, then find magnitude and direction of the resultant.
principles.example: A mass placed equidistant between two equal masses experiences zero net force because forces are equal and opposite.

worked_examples.title: Net Gravitational Force (1D)
worked_examples.problem: Three masses are arranged on a line: $m_1 = 200$ kg at $x = 0$, $m_2 = 300$ kg at $x = 5.0$ m, and $m_3 = 100$ kg at $x = 2.0$ m. Find the net gravitational force on $m_3$.

step_by_step.explanation: Force from $m_1$: attractive, so toward left (negative x). Force from $m_2$: attractive, so toward right (positive x).

worked_examples.concept_applied: Forces along a line add with signs; direction matters.

worked_examples.title: Net Gravitational Force (2D)
worked_examples.problem: Three masses are at the vertices of a right triangle: $m_A = 500$ kg at $(0,0)$, $m_B = 300$ kg at $(4,0)$ m, and $m_C = 400$ kg at $(0,3)$ m. Find the net gravitational force on $m_A$.

step_by_step.explanation: Force from $m_B$: along +x. Force from $m_C$: along +y.

worked_examples.concept_applied: When forces are perpendicular, magnitude from Pythagorean theorem, direction from arctan.

image.alt: Vector diagram showing two gravitational forces on a mass and their resultant
image.caption: The net gravitational force is the vector sum of individual forces.

sections.introduction: Avoid these frequent errors when applying Newton's law of gravitation.

classifications.value: Omitting the gravitational constant in calculations
classifications.behavior: Always include $G = 6.67 \times 10^{-11}$ in numerical problems. It is not 1.

classifications.value: For spherical objects, using the radius as the distance between centers incorrectly
characteristics: Using $r$ as the radius of one object
Not adding radii when objects are touching
classifications.behavior: The $r$ in the formula is the center‑to‑center distance. If objects are touching, $r$ is the sum of their radii.

examples.explanation: Two identical spheres of radius 0.5 m touching: student uses $r = 0.5$ m.

classifications.value: Adding forces as scalars when directions differ
characteristics: Adding magnitudes when forces are not collinear
classifications.behavior: Always treat gravitational forces as vectors. Use components or geometry to add them correctly.

examples.explanation: Two equal forces at 90° added as $F + F = 2F$.

classifications.value: Mixing up the gravitational constant $G$ with acceleration due to gravity $g$
classifications.behavior: $g$ is the acceleration due to gravity at a planet's surface (varies with location). $G$ is a universal constant. They are related by $g = GM/R^2$.

characteristics: Getting sign wrong in vector addition
classifications.behavior: Gravitational force is always attractive. Each mass pulls the other toward itself. In vector form, $\vec{F}_{12} = -G \frac{m_1 m_2}{r^2} \hat{r}_{12}$, where $\hat{r}_{12}$ points from $m_1$ to $m_2$.

image.alt: Common mistakes in gravitation problems: forgetting G, using wrong distance, vector addition errors
image.caption: Avoid these common errors when working with Newton's law of gravitation.

summary: Newton's Law of Universal Gravitation states that every mass attracts every other mass with a force $F = G \frac{m_1 m_2}{r^2}$, where $G = 6.67 \times 10^{-11} \, \text{N}\cdot\text{m}^2/\text{kg}^2$ is the universal gravitational constant. The force is always attractive, acts along the line joining the masses, and obeys an inverse‑square law with distance. For spherical objects, $r$ is the distance between centers. This law explains weight as the gravitational force exerted by Earth: $mg = G M_E m / R_E^2$, so $g = G M_E / R_E^2$. $g$ varies with altitude and differs on other planets. When multiple masses are present, the net gravitational force on any mass is the vector sum of the forces from each other mass (superposition). Common mistakes include forgetting $G$, using radius instead of center‑to‑center distance, treating forces as scalars, and confusing $g$ with $G$. Understanding universal gravitation is essential for analyzing planetary motion, satellite orbits, and tidal forces.
